title.title: Pietro Antonio Michelotti an Nicolaus I Bernoulli. Venedig, 29. Mai 1718
1718.05.29: Michelotti, Pietro Antonio (1663-1740) an Bernoulli, Nicolaus (1687-1759)
1718-05-29_Michelotti_Pietro_Antonio-Bernoulli_Nicolaus
Basler Edition der Bernoulli-Briefwechsel

seriesStmt.title: Der Briefwechsel von Nicolaus I Bernoulli (1687-1759)
Michelotti, Pietro Antonio (1673-1740)

note.p: Unter dem Datum von Nic.I B. eigenhändig "Empfg. den 30ten"

div.opener:
Illustris. et Celeb.mo Viro
Nicolao Bernoulli S. P. D. Petrus Ant.us
Michelotti
div.p:
Existimo te bene valere tuisque studiis in-
cumbere Vir Amicissime. Ego quoque horis a praxi
vacuis literis operam do: et quoniam omnia
quæae ad meæae Exercitationis compositionem
faciunt investigo; perlego omnes authores qui
de eâadem re scripsêere. Incidi itaque in an-
glicum libellum Doctoris Chyne qui plura ad
separationes Fluidorum pertinentia in corpo-
re Animali ,
pertinentia proponit. Inter alia
asserit ; , separatam cui dato tempore cuiusvis
liquoris quantitatem esse ut orificia canalium
separantium directèe, et ut celeritates ad
respectiva orificia reciprocèe. Demonstravit
veròo Celeber. Hermannus Phoronom. lib. 2 cap. X/>pag.
m. mea 214 quantitates liquorūum æaequali tempore
per quæaelibet orificia æaequabili motu fluentia esse in
composita ratione ex rationibus orificiorum et velo-
citatum quibus liquores, quisque per suum fo-
ramen erumpunt. Videtur itaque lapsu s m fuisse
Doctorēem Chyne, nisi fortasse supposuerit minorem
velocitatem in Fluido erumpente ex orificiis maio-
ribus, maiorem veròo in exeunte per minora orificia.
Peto abs te tuum iudicium super hac re. Scio
equidem velocitatem fluidi datâa vi currentis
(quando per canalem duos canales maioris et mi-
noris orificii debere esse maiorem in canali
angustiore, minorem veròo in ampliore: quando
separata Fluidi quantitas æaequali tempore ex utroque canali,
utrobique debet esse æaequalis. At quando compa-
ramus li quantitates liquorum per quæaelibet
orificia inæaequalibus velocitatibus f æaequali tem-
pore fluentium; fieri potest ut liquorūum
per maiora orificia fluentium celeritates
sint maiores. Falsa itaque mihi videtur Chyne
propositio.

Asserit 2.o ipse Chyne quod separatio seu secretio
cuiuslibet Fluidi fit duorum motuum compo-
sitione, idest motu propagato iuxta canalis
longitudinem, et altero motu transverso
propagato versus canalis latera. Id veròo
deducit ex hoc quod Sanguis movetur intra
arterias directione a corde propagata per
arteriarum longitudinem; et præaeter a ea
premit undiquaque ad latera arteriarum
directione perpendiculari in quolibet puncto
ad latera ipsarum arteriarum continentium.
Hinc difficultas oboritur. Nam pressiones Fluidorum
in Statu manenti existentiam fiunt quidem iuxta
directiones perpendiculares ipsis vasis continenti-
bus. Sanguis veròo non est in Statu manenti sive
æaequilibrii, agitatur perpetuo a Corde, et ab ar-
teriis elasticis. quomodo Quomodo ergo asserere possumus
eius pressiones fieri secundum lineas lateribus
arteriarum perpendiculares. Anne duorum dic-
torum motuum compositio locum habere
potest in sanguine per arterias fluente
motuque perculso agitativo?

Asserit tertio .
quod Separatio cuiuslibet Fluidi
continget quam facilius fieri possit: si vasculūum
separans, angulum efficiat semirectum cum
arteria ex qua effluere debet ipse liquor san-
guini permixtus. Demonstrationem huius Theo-
rematis non adfert. Puto tamen inveniri posse
ope doctrinæae de Maximis et Minimis. Qua de
re etiam ut tuum addas calculum quæaeso.

Pergit memoratus Chyne et loco demonstratio-
nis sequentia addit: quæae anglicano sermone
cum figura annexa prout ab ipso enuncian-
tur ad Te mitto, eorundem explicationem addendo.
Quam tu corrigere et illustrare poteris.

quote.foreign:
This were well worth the observing (if it be possi-
ble) in Animals; but it must be in live ones, before
their parts have altered their positions. And here
it were worth the examining likewise; whither
what Mr. Newton has demonstrated (Schol. prop.
35 lib. 2 Princ. Phil. Math.) about the resistance
of Conical Figures, obtains in AnimalBodies
Bodys , . For tho his demonstration be only con-
cerning Convex Conees, yet the same obtains
in Concave ones, wherfore seing the Artery bet-
wixt ony only two Branchings if a Conus truncatus,
it may be represented by the Figure CEBGF;Das "G" wurde korrigiert.Die Figur stammt aus George Cheyne, A New Theory of Continu'd Fevers, 1701, p. 3.
Now seing the Diameter CB of the Base of this
conus truncatus, and the diameter FG of the
conus abscissus FDGS, as likewise their distance,
OD, may be all be had; it is evident that the
intire cone CBGSH may be had likewise: Wherfore Wherefore
Bisect the distance OD in Q; and if it be found
(having drawn CQ) that QS is equal to QC,
then the conus truncatus CEBGF (among all of the same base and altitude) giv's the least
resistance to the Blood flowing from O to D.
I am enclin'd to think this may obtain in the
truncs of the great Arterys; betwixt their bran-
chings.Die Schreibweise mit Satzpunkt und öffnender Klammer folgt hier der Originalpublikation, aus der zitiert wurde. (for no further if to be considered) This I
reccomend recommend to be examin'd for the honour of that
great Man, who has cor crouded up in this Scho-
lium (not mention the rest of his admirable
book) a vast number (if retail'd) of most
charming and useful Truths.

To come now to the Business; The Testiculi humani
are granted by every one, to be Glands: and
Bellini
have has found the length of the complica-
ted Artery in one of them, to be 300 Ells, and
the altitude of one of these Glands, (when
freed of its integuments) to be \frac{1}{16} Ell: Whence
I conclude, there must be 4800 Plications or
Circumvolutions in one of these, Proximèe. He
likewise asserts, That (cæaeteris paribus), if two Fluids
of the same nature, with equal Velocities, the
one be forced into a Canal of the same number
and lengths of complications, as are in the forsaid
Glands, and the other into a streight canal of the
same length; The Velocity (in or about their exits)
of the first fluid, to that a t f
of the second will be as 1 to 4800.
He has not indeed subjoyn'd the Demonstration;
But if we suppose the Artery to ly in Plice or
folds of such number and lengths, as we have
just now determined; (wich which is perhaps not
far from truth:) and if we suppose the Tarning
Turnings of the Plice to be circular; (which pe-
raphs rhaps may follow from this, that seing
a Circle is the only Figure ordinat of an infini-
te number of equal Sides, and equal Angles; it
must be the only curve, which can make in
all its parts, the Angle of Incidence equal to
the Angle of Reflection, and consequently the
only Curve in which a Fluid wou'd most easily
turn) and likewise the Arch in which they turn
to be a Semicircle: (which it must be, if the
sides run Parallel after the turning; and univer-
sally, if the sides produc'd make any Angle from
the quantity thereof the quantity of the arch in
which they turn, may be determined.) I say, from
these Data the former proportion may be by
Calculation examined; or perhaps more briefly
by experiment, thus.

Take a Pipe of Metal of any Diameter, and fold
it into any determin'd number of Plicæae, whos whose sides
may run parallel, and whose lengths may be \frac{1}{16}Korrektur im Zähler ell:
Then by a weight force a liquor through it and obser-
ve the tieme time
beetwixt betwixt the first entry of the
liquor into the complicated Canal, and it's first
appar appearance at the other orifice; Then
take another streight on one of the same lenght length
with the former and with the same weight force
the Fluid th o r ough it; observing the same
way, the time of it's passage. The lenghts lengths being
the same, the velocities shall be as the time of
passing reciprocally, as is known. Having thus got
the proportion of their velocities in any one
determined number of Plicæae, we may (by the rule
of Three) have their Proportions in any assignd
number thereof thereof. Supposing then that this
great Man has found the truth of the forsaid
Proportion from some such way, as on one of these;
it follows that in every turning the velocity
must be abated \frac{1}{4800} of the whole proximèe: (for
4800:\frac{4800}{4800}::4800.1.) Now etc.

div.p:
Sensus eorum quæae hactenus ex Chyne transcripsi
sequens mihi videtur.

Postquam asseruit ipse Chyne quod separatio cu-
iusvis liquoris in corpore animali sequeretur quam-
facilius fieri possit, si canalis separans angu-
lum semirectum cum arteria efficeret subdit.
Dignum esset observatione in Animalibus viven
Res laude digna esset observare, si fieri posset,
in Animalibus viventibus priusquam eorum
partes positionem mutaverint, utrum dentur
tales canales secernentes qui angulos semirec-
tos cum ipsis arteriis efficiant. Similiterque
examinandum esset in anne quod demonstra-
vit Newtonus (schol. prop. 35 lib. 2 Princ. Phil.
Mathem.) de resistentia figurarum conica-
rum locum habeat in corporibus animalibus;
etenim ista demonstratio tametsi conos convexos
duntaxat con respiciat, nihilominus tamen
locum habet etiam in conis concavis sive
excavatis. Quamobrem quoniam arteria inter
singulos ipsiu suos binos ramos videtur esse co-
nus concavus truncatus, poterit representa-
ri per figuram CEBGF; Nunc quia diameter
CB huius coni truncati, et diameter FG abscissi FDGS,
ut etiam eorum distantia OD, hæaec omnia haberi pos-
sunt; evidens est quod etiam haberi poterit inte-
ger conus CBGHS: quapropter Bisectâa distantiâa
OD in Q; et si id inveniri potest, (ductâa CQ) ita
ut QS sit =CQ; tunc conus truncatus CEBGF
(inter omnes eiusdem basis et altitudinis) dat mi-
nimam resistentiam sanguini iterfacienti
ab O ad D.

De hac re peto a Te Vir amicissime ulteriorem
explicationem et demonstrationem, atque in
hunc finem figuram authoris hic annexam
mitto.

Venio nunc ad paragraphum, qui incipit. To come
now to the Business; The Testiculi humani etc.

Propositionem aliquam Bellini de motu seminis
per canaliculos, Testiculos humanos constituent ium es exami-
nare et illustrare conatur D.r Chyne in isto para-
grapho. Incipit itque sic. Omnes

Omnes concedunt humanos Testiculos esse Glandulas
sive arteriolas plicatas in plurimas plicas: et Bellini
invenit longitudinem complicatæae arteriolæae in uno
testiculo humano esse 300 ulnas florentinasMassangabe nachweisen (Entsprechung in heutiger Massangabe)., alti-
tudinem vero eiusdem testiculi suis tegumentis re-
center spoliati esse \frac{1}{16}Im Nenner ist die Zahl nicht gut lesbar, es könnte auch "18" lauten. ulnæae florentinæae. Undèe con-
cludit debere esse testiculum humanum ita
compositum, ut ille canaliculus qui in longitu-
dinem extensus implet 300 ulnas florentinas,
plicatus sit in 4800 plicas quam proxime.
Bellini autem verba hæaec sunt. cogita trecentas
"illas ulnas florentinas, quas implet universa lon-
"gitudo humani testiculi, si omnes canaliculi ex qui-
"bus componitur explicentur, et in rectum extenden-
"tur: inde cogita quantæae sit altitudinis ipse testi-
"culus hominis in suo naturali statu, nempe cum
"canaliculi, ex quibus componitur, in suis naturalibus
"plicis persistunt; inveniesque illum nudatum mem-
"branis esse altum quanta est semidigiti longi-
"tudo: tum calculum subducito et inveni, et inve-
"ni quot semidiametri contineantur in tre-
"centis ulnis, et invenies contineri semidigitos
"quatuor mille cum octingentis; et ex his dedu-
"ces liquidūum fluens per canaliculum trecentarūum
"ulnarum in rerum longum extensarūum fluere
"eo momento velocitatis quod ad velocitatem per
"per eundem canalem ita inflexūum ut evadat
"semidigitalis altitudinis, eandem proportionem
"habet, quam habent quatuor quatuor millia octingenta
"ad unum. Hæaec Bellinus; ex quo quæae scripsit, excer-
pit psit
D.r Chyne. Te autem rogo ut mihi calculum
exhibeas; et methodum inveniendi, contineri
in 300 ulnis florentinis 4800 semidigitos, commu-
nices; Addasque simul demonstrationem proposi-
tionis Bellinianæae. Etenim subdit D.r Chyne
D.r Bellini revera non dedit huius propositionis
demonstrationem; verùum (inquit ipse Chyne)
si supponamus arteriam testiculum humanūum compo-
nentem esse canaliculūum plicatum in 4800 plicas,
et has plicas esse circulares; (id quod fortasse ex eo se-
qui potest quod circulus est sola figura ordinata
numeri infiniti æaequalium laterum et angulorūum,
ideoque sola curva, quæae in omnibus suis partibus potest
efficere angulūum incidentiæae = angulo reflexionis,
et consequenter sola curva, in qua moveri potest
sive circumagi Fluidum facillimée potest quod-
vis Fluidum Fluidum) et pariter si supponamus
arcum in quem plicæae sunt dispositæae esse semicirculūum
(id quod esse debet si latera post circumvolutionem
iacent parallella parallela , et universaliter si latera produc-
ta constituunt angulum aliquem, ex cuius quan-
titate, determinari potest quantitas arcus in quo
plicæae sunt dispositæae) hisce omnibus datis inquit
Chyne memorata proportio calculo examinari
potest; aut fortassis brevius per experientiam
hac ratione. Rogo ut tuum addas calculum
in suppositione plicarum circularium, et
ut demonstres cur et quando plicæae possint, de-
beantque esse circulares.

Accipit D.r Chyne canalem metallicūum alicuius diame-
tri, ipsumque contorquet in quemlibet determina-
tum plicarūum numerūum, quarūum latera sint paralle-
la, et quarūum longitudo sit \frac{1}{16} unius ulnæae. Tunc
aliqua vi aut aliquo pondere propellit liquorem per
canalem ita plicatūum tempusque quod liquor
impendit transeundo ab immissario ad emissa-
riūum accuratèe observat. Eundem postea liquo-
rem eadem vi propellit per eundem canalēem
metallicum sine plicis in rectum extensūum
tempus transitus sive me itineris notando.
Temporibus observatis et habitis concludit, ve-
locitates esse ut tempora reciproce; quia canalis longitu-
do eadem est. Per regulam trium (inventàa antea
velocitate in aliquo determinato plicarum nu-
mero) dicit se inventurūum velocitatūum propor-
tionem in quolibet determinato plicarum nu-
mero. Supponens tandem quod hac via
aut consimili invenerit Bellinus veritatem
enunciatæae propositionis concludit quod in qua-
libet plica debet velocitas imminui \frac{1}{4800} quam-
proxime quia 4800.\frac{4800}{4800}::4800.1.

Hæaec tibi omnia examinanda et accurate
illustranda corrigendaque propono quam
primum fieri poterit.
div.closer:
Vale Vir Illustriss.e
mihique ut assoles favere perge. Dabam
Venetiisa. d. 29 Maii 1718.
